Through a door he sees the end of a cheap b over the back of which is a pair of pajamas and a nightie Ernie exits and closes the door.
(tears in her eyes) Welcome home, Mr. Bailey.
(overcome) Well, I'll be... Mary, Mary, where  did you...
They rush into each other's arms and hold each other in  ecstasy.
Bert and Ernie, standing in the pouring rain, start singi "I Love You Truly."
They remain embraced.
Oh, Mary...
Remember the night we broke the  windows in this old house? This is  what I wished for.
Darling, you're wonderful.
They finish their song, and Ernie kisses Bert on the fore Bert slams Ernie's hat on his head.

head_text.subj: EXT. SLUM STREET BEDFORD FALLS DAY TWO YEARS LATER

text: In front of one of the miserable shacks that line the str are two vehicles. One of them is George Bailey's rickety  car, and the other is an even more rickety truck piled hi with household goods. The Martini family is moving. The f consists of Martini, his wife and four kid of various age from two to ten.  George and Mary are helping the Martini move. About a dozen neighbors crowd around. Martini and  George, assisted by three of the Martini children, are  carrying out the last of the furniture.  As they emerge f the house, one of the neighbors, Schultz, calls out:
Martini, you rented a new house?
Rent? (to George) You hear what he say, Mr. Bailey?
What's that?
I own the house. Me, Giuseppe Martini.  I own my own house. No more we live  like pigs in thisa Potter's Field.  Hurry, Maria.
Yes...
Come on... (to Mary) Bring the baby. (to Martini) I'll bring the kids in the car.
Oh, thank you, Mr. Bailey.
Mary gets in the front seat of the car, with the baby in arms.
All right, kids  here  get in here.  Now get right up on the seat there.   Get the...  get the goat!
The family goat gets in the back seat with the three kids
Goodbye, everybody!
All in...
The rickety caravan starts off down the street, to the ch of the neighbors.

Sign hanging from a tree "Welcome to Bailey Park." CAMERA PANS TO follow George's car and the old truck laden with  furniture as they pass  we hear Martini's voice singing " Sole Mio." Bailey Park is a district of new small houses, not all alike, but each individual. New lawns here and th and young trees. It has the promise when built up of bein pleasant little middle class section.
George and Mary are on the porch of the new house, with t Martinis lined up before them.
Mr. and Mrs. Martini, welcome home.   The Martinis cross themselves.

Sam Wainwright is standing in front of his big black town car. Sam is the epitome of successful, up-and-coming  businessman. His wife, in the car, is a very attractive,  sophisticated-looking lady, dripping with furs and jewels Sam is watching George across the street.
That old George... he's always making  a speech. (to George) Hee-haw! (wiggles his hands)
(to Mary) Sam Wainwright!
Oh, who cares. (to Mrs. Martini,  giving her loaf of  bread) Bread! That this house may never  know hunger.
Mrs. Martini crosses herself.
(giving her salt) Salt! That life may always have  flavor.
(handing bottle to  Martini) And wine!  That joy and prosperity  may reign forever. Enter the Martini  castle!
The Martinis cross themselves, shaking hands all around. kids enter, with screams of delight. Mrs. Martini kisses  Mary.

head_text.subj: INT. POTTER'S OFFICE IN BANK DAY

text: Potter seated in his wheelchair at his desk, with his goo beside him.  His rent collector, Reineman, is talking,  pointing to maps spread out on the desk.
Look, Mr. Potter, it's no skin off  my nose. I'm just your little rent  collector.  But you can't laugh off  this Bailey Park any more. Look at  it.
A buzzer is heard, and Potter snaps on the dictaphone on desk.
Congressman Blatz is here to see  you.
(to dictaphone) Oh, tell the congressman to wait. (to Reineman) Go on.

Fifteen years ago, a half-dozen houses  stuck here and there. (indicating map) There's the old cemetery, squirrels,  buttercups, daisies. Used to hunt  rabbits there myself. Look at it  today. Dozens of the prettiest little  homes you ever saw.  Ninety per cent  owned by suckers who used to pay  rent to you. Your Potter's Field, my  dear Mr. Employer, is becoming just  that. And are the local yokels making  with those David and Goliath  wisecracks!
Oh, they are, are they? Even though  they know the Baileys haven't made a  dime out of it.
You know very well why. The Baileys  were all chumps. Every one of these  homes is worth twice what it cost  the Building and Loan to build. If I  were you, Mr. Potter...
(interrupting) Well, you are not me.
(as he leaves) As I say, it's no skin off my nose.  But one of these days this bright  young man is going to be asking George  Bailey for a job.
Reineman exits.
The Bailey family has been a boil on  my neck long enough.
He flips the switch on the dictaphone.
Yes, sir?
Come in here.

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET IN BAILEY PARK DAY

text: George and Mary are talking to Sam Wainwright in front of the latter's car. Hs wife, Jane, is now out of the car.
We just stopped in town to take a  look at the new factory, and then  we're going to drive on down to  Florida.
Oh...
Why don't you have your friends join  us?
Why, sure. Hey, why don't you kids  drive down with us, huh?
Oh, I'm afraid I couldn't get away,  Sam.
Still got the nose to the old  grindstone, eh? Jane, I offered to  let George in on the ground floor in  plastics, and he turned me down cold.
Oh, now, don't rub it in.
I'm not rubbing it in. Well, I guess  we better run along.
There is handshaking all around as Sam and Jane get into  their car.
Awfully glad to have met you, Mary.
Nice meeting you.
Goodbye.
Goodbye, George.
So long, George. See you in the funny  papers.
Goodbye, Sam.
Have fun.
Thanks for dropping around.
(to chauffeur) To Florida! (to George) Hee-haw!
Hee-haw.
The big black limousine glides away, leaving George stand with his arm around Mary, gazing broodingly after it. The slowly walk over to George's old car and look at it silen
Potter is lighting a big cigar which he has just given Ge The goon is beside Potter's chair, as usual.
Thank you, sir. Quite a cigar, Mr.  Potter.
You like it? I'll send you a box.
(nervously) Well, I... I suppose I'll find out  sooner or later, but just what exactly  did you want to see me about?

(laughs) George, now that's just what I like  so much about you. (pleasantly and  smoothly) George, I'm an old man, and most  people hate me. But I don't like  them either, so that makes it all  even. You know just as well as I do  that I run practically everything in  this town but the Bailey Building  and Loan. You know, also, that for a  number of years I've been trying to  get control of it... or kill it. But  I haven't been able to do it. You  have been stopping me. In fact, you  have beaten me, George, and as anyone  in this county can tell you, that  takes some doing. Take during the  depression, for instance. You and I  were the only ones that kept our  heads. You saved the Building and  Loan, and I saved all the rest.
Yes. Well, most people say you stole  all the rest.

The envious ones say that, George,  the suckers. Now, I have stated my  side very frankly. Now, let's look  at your side.  Young man, twenty- seven, twenty-eight...  married,  making, say... forty a week.
(indignantly) Forty-five!

Forty-five. Forty-five. Out of which,  after supporting your mother, and  paying your bills, you're able to  keep, say, ten, if you skimp. A child  or two comes along, and you won't  even be able to save the ten. Now,  if this young man of twenty-eight  was a common, ordinary yokel, I'd  say he was doing fine. But George  Bailey is not a common, ordinary  yokel. He's an intelligent, smart,  ambitious young man  who hates his  job  who hates the Building and  Loan almost as much as I do. A young  man who's been dying to get out on  his own ever since he was born. A  young man... the smartest one of the  crowd, mind you, a young man who has  to sit by and watch his friends go  places, because he's trapped.  Yes,  sir, trapped into frittering his  life away playing nursemaid to a lot  of garlic-eaters.  Do I paint a  correct picture, or do I exaggerate?
(mystified) Now what's your point, Mr. Potter?
My point? My point is, I want to  hire you.
(dumbfounded) Hire me?
I want you to manage my affairs, run  my properties. George, I'll start  you out at twenty thousand dollars a  year.
George drops his cigar on his lap. He nervously brushes o the sparks from his clothes.
(flabbergasted) Twenty thou... twenty thousand dollars  a year?

You wouldn't mind living in the nicest  house in town, buying your wife a  lot of fine clothes, a couple of  business trips to New York a year,  maybe once in a while Europe. You  wouldn't mind that, would you, George?
Would I? (looking around  skeptically) You're not talking to somebody else  around here, are you? You know, this  is me, you remember me? George Bailey.
Oh, yes, George Bailey. Whose ship  has just come in  providing he has  brains enough to climb aboard.
Well, what about the Building and  Loan?
Oh, confound it, man, are you afraid  of success? I'm offering you a three  year contract at twenty thousand  dollars a year, starting today. Is  it a deal or isn't it?
Well, Mr. Potter, I... I... I know I  ought to jump at the chance, but  I... I just...  I wonder if it would  be possible for you to give me twenty- four hours to think it over?
Sure, sure, sure. You go on home and  talk about it to your wife.
I'd like to do that.
In the meantime, I'll draw up the  papers.
All right, sir.
(offers hand) Okay, George?
(taking his hand) Okay, Mr. Potter.

As they shake hands, George feels a physical revulsion.  Potter's hand feels like a cold mackerel to him. In that  moment of physical contact he knows he could never be  associated with this man.  George drops his hand with a  shudder. He peers intently into Potter's face.

(vehemently) No... no... no... no, now wait a  minute, here!  I don't have to talk  to anybody!  I know right now, and  the answer is no! NO!  Doggone it! (getting madder all  the time) You sit around here and you spin  your little webs and you think the  whole world revolves around you and  your money. Well, it doesn't, Mr.  Potter!  In the... in the whole vast  configuration of things, I'd say you  were nothing but a scurvy little  spider. You...
He turns and shouts at the goon, impassive as ever beside Potter's wheelchair.
...And that goes for you too!
As George opens the office door to exit, he shouts at Mr. Potter's secretary in the outer office
And it goes for you too!

head_text.subj: INT. BEDROOM GEORGE AND MARY'S HOUSE NIGHT

text: The room is modestly furnished with just a cheap bed, a c or two, and a dresser. Mary is asleep in the bed. As Geor comes in, his head is filled with many confusing thoughts relating to incidents in his past life.
You wouldn't mind living in the nicest  house in town. Buying your wife a  lot of fine clothes, going to New  York on a business trip a couple of  times a year.  Maybe to Europe once  in a while.
George takes off his hat and coat, moves over to the dres and stares at his reflection in the mirror.

I know what I'm going to do tomorrow  and the next day and next year and  the year after that. I'm shaking the  dust of this crummy little town off  my feet, and I'm going to see the  world... And I'm going to build  things. I'm going to build air fields.   I'm going to build skyscrapers a  hundred stories high. I'm going to  build a bridge a mile long.
While the above thoughts are passing through George's hea his attention is caught by a picture on the wall near the dresser:
It is the sketch of George lassoing the moon that we firs saw in Mary's living room. The lettering reads: "George L The Moon."
What is it you want, Mary? You want  the moon? If you do, just say the  word; I'll throw a lasso around it  and pull it down for you.
Mary is now awake, and starts singing their theme song:
(singing) Buffalo Gals, won't you come out  tonight, won't you come out tonight,  won't you come out tonight.
George crosses over and sits on the edge of the bed.
Hi.
Hi.
Mary Hatch, why in the world did you  ever marry a guy like me?
To keep from being an old maid.
You could have married Sam Wainwright  or anybody else in town.
I didn't want to marry anybody else  in town. I want my baby to look like  you.
You didn't even have a honeymoon. I  promised you... (does a double take) ...Your what?
My baby.
(incredulously) You mean... Mary, you on the nest?
George Bailey lassos stork.
Lassos the stork! You mean you...  What is it, a boy or a girl?
Mary nods her head happily.
Over the following SERIES OF SHOTS we hear the voices of  Joseph and Clarence in Heaven.

head_text.subj: EXT. MAIN STREET BEDFORD FALLS NIGHT

text: George is crossing the street, heading for the offices of the Building and Loan.
Now, you've probably already guessed  that George never leaves Bedford  Falls.
No!
Mary had her baby, a boy.
Mary sitting on the floor playing with a baby. A little b is in a playpen nearby.
Then she had another one  a girl.
Mary is busy hanging wallpaper and painting the old place
Day after day she worked away remaking  the old Granville house into a home.
George has just come into the hall. He is obviously tired and discouraged as he starts up the stairs. The knob on t banister comes off in his hand.
Night after night George came back  late from the office. Potter was  bearing down hard.
A group of men, obviously just drafted, marching along in camp.
Then came a war.
Mrs. Bailey and other women in Red Cross uniforms busily  sewing, etc.
Ma Bailey and Mrs. Hatch joined the  Red Cross and sewed.

head_text.subj: EXT. TRAIN IN RAILROAD STATION DAY

text: Mary, with portable U.S.O. pushcart, is serving coffee an doughnuts to men leaning from the train.
Mary had two more babies, but still  found time to run the U.S.O.
Sam Wainwright showing set of blueprints to two Army offi
Sam Wainwright made a fortune in  plastic hoods for planes.
Potter is wheeled in toward a long table around which sev men are seated.
Potter became head of the draft board.
(reading from papers) One-A... One-A... One-A...

head_text.subj: EXT. STREET IN BEDFORD FALLS DAY

text: Gower and Uncle Billy are conducting a bond rally from th top of an Army tank.
Gower and Uncle Billy sold war bonds.
Bert, in uniform, moving cautiously with fixed bayonet. S and flashes of gunfire in background.
Bert the cop was wounded in North  Africa.  Got the Silver Star.
Hundreds of planes, flying overhead, with parachutes drop from them.
Ernie, the taxi driver, parachuted  into France.

head_text.subj: EXT. REMAGEN BRIDGE OVER THE RHINE DAY

text: Marty in the foreground, beckoning to soldiers to come on
Marty helped capture the Remagen  Bridge.

head_text.subj: INT. READY ROOM ON AIRCRAFT CARRIER NIGHT

text: Harry is fastening the helmet of his flying clothes. He w as he exits through the door.
Harry... Harry Bailey topped them  all. A Navy flier, he shot down  fifteen planes.

head_text.subj: EXT. OCEAN FROM DECK OF CARRIER NIGHT

text: A flaming plane crashes into the sea.
...two of them as they were about to  crash into a transport full of  soldiers.
Yes, but George...
George, behind the counter, is trying to quiet a crowd of people all clamoring for more ration points.
George? Four-F on account of his  ear, George fought the battle of  Bedford Falls.
George shouts.
Hold on... hold on... hold on now.  Don't you know there's a war on?
George, in the uniform of an air raid warden, is patrolli his beat.
Air raid Warden...
Man beside lighted window pulls down the shade as George  blows his whistle.
George is helping load his old car with scrap paper.
...paper drives...
Wheelbarrow full of junk being dumped onto pile.
...Scrap drives...
...Rubber drives...
Like everybody else, on V-E Day he  wept and prayed.
On V-J Day he wept and prayed again.
Joseph, now show him what happened  today.
Yes, sir.

head_text.subj: EXT. BEDFORD FALLS STREET WINTER DAY

text: George is walking along the sidewalk reading a newspaper. is a raw, gusty day, and his overcoat and muffler flap in the breeze.  Draped around one arm is a large Christmas  wreath. Under his other arm are several more copies of th paper.
This morning, day before Christmas,  about ten A.M. Bedford Falls time...
George comes to where Ernie, the taxi driver, is standing the sidewalk.
(holding out paper) Hi, Ernie, look at that.

The front page of the paper, the Bedford Falls Sentinel. headline reads: "PRESIDENT DECORATES HARRY BAILEY  LOCAL  BOY WINS CONGRESSIONAL MEDAL OF HONOR". The subhead tells a plan for a giant jubilee and parade, to be followed by banquet, in honor of Commander Harry Bailey, U.S.N. on hi way home from Washington after receiving the Congressiona Medal of Honor. There's a large picture of President Trum pinning the coveted medal on Harry's bosom, in the midst dignitaries; a picture of the transport which Harry saved Practically the whole front page is devoted to the story.
(kidding) Gonna snow again.
(outraged) What do you mean  it's gonna snow  again?  Look at the headlines.
I know  I know  I know. I think  it's marvelous.
Gower comes running across the street from his drugstore joins them.
(reading) Commander Harry Bailey. Mr. Gower,  look at this  the second page. (gives them papers) Now look, this is for you. This is  for you, this is for you. (as he leaves) See you again.
Uncle Billy is walking along the street, humming happily himself. He sees some men decorating the Court House with banners and bunting  there is a huge sign reading: "Welco Home Harry Bailey"
(calls out) Be sure you spell the name right.

head_text.subj: INT. OUTER OFFICE BUILDING AND LOAN DAY

text: The offices are unchanged, still small-time and old-fashi The same office force, albeit a few years older: Cousin T and Cousin Eustace. Seated on a chair is a middle-aged ma with a brief case. The outer door opens and George enters
Extra! Extra! Read all about it!
Cousin Tilly and Cousin Eustace are talking on the phone.
George! George! It's Harry now on  long distance from Washington!
Harry! What do you know about that?
He reversed the charges. It's okay,  isn't it?

What do you mean it's okay?  For a  hero? (takes the phone) Harry!  Oh, you old seven kinds of a  son of a gun. Congratulations!  How's  Mother standing it?... She did? What  do you know... (to Eustace) Mother had lunch with the President's  wife!
Wait till Martha hears about this.
What did they have to eat?
(on phone) What did they have to eat? Harry,  you should see what they're cooking  up in the town for you... Oh, are  they? (to Eustace) The Navy's going to fly Mother home  this afternoon.
In a plane?
What? Uncle Billy? (to Eustace) Has Uncle Billy come in yet?
No, he stopped at the bank first.
(on phone) He's not here right now, Harry.
Cousin Eustace has turned away from George and caught a  glimpse of the man waiting in the chair. This is Carter, bank examiner, come for his annual audit of the books of Building and Loan.
(on phone) But look...
(interrupting) George...
(on phone) ...now tell me about it.
(interrupting) ...George, that man's here again.
What man?
(nervously) Bank... bank examiner.
Oh... (on phone) Talk to Eustace a minute, will you.  I'll be right back.
He gives the phone to Eustace, puts down his wreath and g over to Carter.
They shake hands.
Good morning, sir.
Carter  bank examiner.
Mr. Carter, Merry Christmas.
Merry Christmas.
We're all excited around here. (shows him paper) My brother just got the Congressional  Medal of Honor. The President just  decorated him.
Well, I guess they do those things.  Well, I trust you had a good year.
Good year? Well, between you and me,  Mr. Carter, we're broke.
Yeah, very funny.
Well... (leading him into  office) ...now, come right in here, Mr.  Carter.
(as they go) Although I shouldn't wonder when you  okay reverse charges on personal  long distance calls.
George, shall we hang up?
No, no. He wants to talk to Uncle  Billy.  You just hold on.
(in doorway) Now, if you'll cooperate, I'd like  to finish with you by tonight. I  want to spend Christmas in Elmira  with my family.
I don't blame you at all, Mr. Carter,  Just step right in here. We'll fix  you up.
Uncle Billy is filling out a deposit slip at one of the d
(writing) December twenty-fourth...
He takes a thick envelope from his inside pocket and thum through the bills it contains. It is evidently a large su of money.
Eight thousand...

Potter is being wheeled in by his goon. Various bank offi run over to greet him  he is reading a newspaper. Uncle  Billy has finished filling out his slip, and comes over t taunt Potter, the envelope containing the money in his ha
Well, good morning, Mr. Potter. What's  the news?
He grabs the paper from Potter's hand.
Well, well, well, Harry Bailey wins  Congressional Medal. That couldn't  be one of the Bailey boys? You just  can't keep those Baileys down, now,  can you, Mr. Potter?
How does slacker George feel about  that?
Very jealous, very jealous. He only  lost three buttons off his vest. Of  course, slacker George would have  gotten two of those medals if he had  gone.
Bad ear.
Yes.
Uncle Billy folds Potter's paper over the envelope contai his money, and flings his final taunt at the old man.
After all, Potter, some people like  George had to stay home. Not every  heel was in Germany and Japan!
In a cold rage, Potter grabs his paper and wheels off tow his office. Uncle Billy smiles triumphantly and goes towa deposit window with his deposit slip.
Uncle Billy and bank teller at the  window.
(still chuckling) Good morning, Horace.
Uncle Billy hands the bank book over. The teller opens it starts to punch it with rubber stamps.
I guess you forgot something.
Huh?
You forgot something.
What?
Well, aren't you going to make a  deposit?
Sure, sure I am.
Well, then... it's usually customary  to bring the money with you.
Oh, shucks...
Uncle Billy searches through every pocket he has.
(looks bewildered) I know I had...
The teller, knowing the old man's vagaries, points to one the numerous string tied around his fingers.
How about that one there?
Hmm? Well, I...
Potter is now behind his desk. He spreads the newspaper o in front of him, muttering as he does so.
Bailey...
He sees the envelope, looks inside at the money. Then, to his goon, indicating the office door:
Take me back there. Hurry up. (as they go) Come on, look sharp.
Potter opens the door just a little, and peers through in the bank.

Uncle Billy looks around for the money envelope. It is no there.  He looks puzzled, thinks hard, then a look of con creeps into his eyes. He starts thumping his pockets, wit increasing panic, and looks in the waste paper basket on floor. He finally rushes through the door and out into th street.
(to goon) Take me back.
The goon wheels him back to his desk. He is deep in thoug with a crafty expression on his face.
Uncle Billy running across the street in the direction of the Building and Loan.

head_text.subj: INT. OUTER OFFICE BUILDING AND LOAN DAY

text: George coming from room where he has just left the bank  examiner.
Just make yourself at home, Mr.  Carter.  I'll get those books for  you.
He sees Violet Bick standing there.
Oh, hello, Vi.
George, can I see you for a second?
Why, of course you can. Come on in  the office here.
He hears a noise, and sees Uncle Billy entering the offic
Uncle Billy, talk to Harry. He's on  the telephone.
George and Violet enter his private office. Uncle Billy c hurrying in.
Hurry, Uncle Billy, hurry. Long  distance, Washington.
Hey, here's Harry on the phone.
Harry, your nephew, remember?
(on phone) Here he is.
Uncle Billy picks up the phone and speaks distractedly,  without knowing what he is saying.
(on phone) Hello... hello... Yes, Harry  yes...   everything... everything's fine.
He hangs up agitatedly, muttering to himself as he goes i his own office. Cousin Tilly and Cousin Eustace look afte him, dumbfounded.
I should have my head examined. Eight  thousand dollars. It's got to be  somewhere.
George has just finished writing something, and is slippi the paper into an envelope.
(hands it to her) Here you are.
(bitterly) Character? If I had any character,  I'd...
It takes a lot of character to leave  your home town and start all over  again.  He pulls some money from his  pocket, and offers it to her.
No, George, don't...
Here, now, you're broke, aren't you?
I know, but...
What do you want to do, hock your  furs, and that hat? Want to walk to  New York?  You know, they charge for  meals and rent up there just the  same as they do in Bedford Falls.
(taking money) Yeah  sure...
It's a loan. That's my business.  Building and Loan. Besides, you'll  get a job. Good luck to you.
She looks at him, then says a strange thing.
I'm glad I know you, George Bailey.
She reaches up and kisses him on the cheek, leaving lipst George opens the door for her.
As George and Violet come through the door, they are bein watched by Cousin Tilly, Cousin Eustace and the bank exam who is still waiting to go to work on the books.
Say hello to New York for me.
Yeah  yeah... sure I will.
Now, let's hear from you...
Violet sees the lipstick on George's cheek, and dabs at i with her handkerchief.
What's the matter? Merry Christmas,  Vi.
Merry Christmas, George.
She exits.
Mr. Bailey...
Oh, Mr. Carter, I'm sorry. I'll be  right with you. (to Cousin Tilly) Uncle Billy in?
Yeah, he's in his office.

head_text.subj: INT. DOORWAY TO UNCLE BILLY'S OFFICE DAY

text: As George opens the door he sees Uncle Billy frantically  looking for the missing envelope. The office is in a mess drawers are opened, and papers scattered on the floor and the desk.
Unc... What's going on? The bank  examiner's here, and I...
(in dismay) He's here?
Yeah, yeah. He wants the accounts  payable...
George stops short, suddenly aware of the tragic old eyes looking up at him.
What's the matter with you?
Uncle Billy gestures nervously for George to come in. He  does so and closes the door.

Cousin Tilly is at her switchboard, and Cousin Eustace  standing beside her. Carter is still waiting in the doorw to his office.  Suddenly the door opens and George comes  striding out. He goes directly to the safe and starts  searching, but doesn't find the money. Then he goes to th cash drawer in the counter, and looks through it.
Eustace...
Yeah?
Come here a minute.
Cousin Eustace runs over to George.
Did you see Uncle Billy with any  cash last night?
He had it on his desk counting it  before he closed up.

head_text.subj: EXT. MAIN STREET BEDFORD FALLS DAY

text: Uncle Billy and George are retracing the former's steps  through the snow, looking everywhere for the missing mone They pause for a moment on the sidewalk.
Now look, did you buy anything?
Nothing. Not even a stick of gum.
All right. All right. Now we'll go  over every step you took since you  left the house.
This way.
They continue on down the street on their search.

head_text.subj: EXT. WINDOW OF POTTER'S OFFICE IN BANK DAY

text: Potter is peering through the slats of the Venetian blind watching them as they go.

head_text.subj: EXT. MAIN STREET BEDFORD FALLS DAY

text: George and Uncle Billy continue their search.

A shabby, old-fashioned, gas-lit room which has been turn almost inside out and upside down in an effort to locate missing money. Drawers of an old secretary have been pull out and are on the floor. Every conceivable place which m have been used by Uncle Billy to put the money has been  searched. George, his hair rumpled, is feverishly pursuin the search. Uncle Billy is seated behind the desk, his he on his hands.
And did you put the envelope in your  pocket?
Yeah... yeah... maybe... maybe...
(shouts) Maybe  maybe! I don't want any maybe.   Uncle Billy, we've got to find that  money!
(piteously) I'm no good to you, George. I...
Listen to me. Do you have any secret  hiding place here in the house?  Someplace you could have put it?  Someplace to hide the money?
(exhausted) I've been over the whole house, even  in rooms that have been locked ever  since I lost Laura.
Uncle Billy starts sobbing hysterically. George grabs him the lapels and shakes him.
(harshly) Listen to me! Listen to me! Think!  Think!
(sobbing) I can't think any more, George. I  can't think any more. It hurts...
George jerks him to his feet and shakes him. Uncle Billy  stands before him like a frisked criminal, all his pocket hanging out, empty. George's eyes and manner are almost  maniacal.
(screaming at him) Where's that money, you stupid, silly  old fool? Where's the money?  Do you  realize what this means? It means  bankruptcy and scandal, and prison!
He throws Uncle Billy down into his chair, and still shou at him:
That's what it means! One of us is  going to jail! Well, it's not going  to be me!
George turns and heads for the door, kicking viciously at waste basket on the floor as he goes. Uncle Billy remains sobbing at the table, his head in his arms.

Janie (aged eight) is seated at the piano playing "Hark, Herald Angels Sing," which she practices during the remai of this scene. There is a Christmas tree all decorated ne the fireplace. At a large table Mary is busy putting  cellophane bows and decorations on gift packages. At a sm table Pete (aged nine) is seated with pad and pencil in t throes of composition.  On the floor Tommy (aged three) i playing with a toy vacuum cleaner. We hear the SOUND of a door open and close. Mary turns and sees George enter the hall, a slight powdering of snow on his head and shoulder
As George comes into the house.
Hello darling.
Hello Daddy, hello daddy.
(indicating tree) How do you like it?
George sneezes violently.
Bless you!
Did you bring the wreath?
Did you bring the Christmas wreath?
What? What wreath?
The Merry Christmas wreath for the  window.
(gruffly) No. I left it at the office.
Is it snowing?
Yeah, just started.
Where's your coat and hat?
Left them at the office.
Mary stares at him, aware that something unusual has happ
What's the matter?
(bitterly) Nothing's the matter. Everything's  all right.
George slumps into an armchair and lifts Tommy onto his l Mary is helping Pete decorate the Christmas tree.

Go on, Pete, you're a big boy.  You  can put the star up. Way up at the  top. That's it.  Fill in that little  bare spot right there.  That's it. (to George) Isn't it wonderful about Harry?   We're famous, George. I'll bet I had  fifty calls today about the parade,  the banquet. Your mother's so excited,  she...
During this scene, George has been sitting in the chair,  hugging Tommy to him, and crying quietly. Mary realizes t something is seriously wrong, and breaks off. Janie is  thumping away at the piano.
Must she keep playing that?
(hurt) I have to practice for the party  tonight, Daddy.
Mommy says we can stay up till  midnight and sing Christmas carols.
Can you sing, Daddy?
(to George) Better hurry and shave. The families  will be here soon.
(rising from chair) Families!  I don't want the families  over here!
Mary leads him out toward the kitchen.
Come on out in the kitchen with me  while I finish dinner.
They exit with Tommy hanging onto George's coat-tails, an pulling at him. CAMERA PANS WITH them.
Excuse me... excuse me...
As they go toward kitchen.
Have a hectic day?
(bitterly) Oh, yeah, another big red letter day  for the Baileys.
Daddy, the Browns next door have a  new car. You should see it.
(turns on him) Well, what's the matter with our  car?  Isn't it good enough for you?
Yes, Daddy.
(tugging at coat) Excuse me, excuse me...
They come through the door.
(annoyed) Excuse you for what?
I burped!
All right, darling, you're excused.  Now go upstairs and see what little  Zuzu wants.
Tommy leaves, and Mary turns to the stove.
Zuzu! What's the matter with Zuzu?
Oh, she's got a cold. She's in bed.  Caught it coming home from school.   They gave her a flower for a prize  and she didn't want to crush it so  she didn't button up her coat.
What is it, a sore throat or what?
Just a cold. The doctor says it's  nothing serious.
The doctor? Was the doctor here?
Yes, I called him right away. He  says it's nothing to worry about.
Is she running a temperature? What  is it?
Just a teensie one  ninety-nine,  six.  She'll be all right.
George paces about the kitchen, worried.

Gosh, it's this old house. I don't  know why we don't all have pneumonia.  This drafty old barn! Might as well  be living in a refrigerator. Why did  we have to live here in the first  place and stay around this measly,  crummy old town?
(worried) George, what's wrong?
Wrong? Everything's wrong! You call  this a happy family? Why did we have  to have all these kids?
(coming in) Dad, how do you spell "frankincense"?
(shouts) I don't know. Ask your mother.
George goes toward doorway.
Where're you going?
Going up to see Zuzu.
We hear his footsteps as he leaves. Mary looks after him, puzzled and concerned, then comes over to Pete.
He told me to write a play for  tonight.
F-R-A-N-K-I-N...
The knob on the banister comes off in his hand, and for a moment he has an impulse to hurl it into the living room. Then, he replaces the knob, and goes on up the stairs.

The SOUND of Janie at the piano can be heard, the same  monotonous rhythm over and over. Zuzu (aged six) is sitti up in her bed, the lamp burning beside her. She is holdin her prize flower.  George tiptoes in. Then, as he sees sh awake, he comes over, sitting on the edge of her bed.
Hi, Daddy.
Well, what happened to you?
I won a flower.
She starts to get out of bed.
Wait now. Where do you think you're  going?
Want to give my flower a drink.
All right, all right. Here, give  Daddy the flower. I'll give it a  drink.
She shakes her head and presses the flower to her. A few  petals fall off. She picks them up.
Look, Daddy... paste it.
Yeah, all right. Now, I'll paste  this together.

She hands him the fallen petals and the flower. He turns back to Zuzu, pretending to be tinkering with the flower. sticks the fallen petals in his watch pocket, rearranges flower, and then turns back to Zuzu.
There it is, good as new.
Give the flower a drink.
George puts the flower in a glass of water on the table b her bed.
Now, will you do something for me?
They whisper.
What?
Will you try to get some sleep?
I'm not sleepy. I want to look at my  flower.
I know  I know, but you just go to  sleep, and then you can dream about  it, and it'll be a whole garden.
It will?
Uh-huh.
She closes her eyes and relaxes on the bed. George pulls covers over her. He bends down and his lips touch a tendr of the child's hair. Then he gets up and tiptoes out of t room.
Janie is still pounding with grim determination at the pi Pete is seated at the table writing. Tommy is playing wit his toy vacuum cleaner. The telephone rings.
Telephone.
Mary comes in and picks up the phone.
I'll get it. (on phone) Hello. Yes, this is Mrs. Bailey.
George enters shot, and stands listening to her.
Oh, thank you, Mrs. Welch. I'm sure  she'll be all right. The doctor says  that she ought to be out of bed in  time to have her Christmas dinner.
Is that Zuzu's teacher?
(hand over receiver) Yes.
Let me speak to her.
He snatches the phone from Mary.

(on phone) Hello. Hello, Mrs. Welch?  This is  George Bailey. I'm Zuzu's father.  Say, what kind of a teacher are you  anyway?  What do you mean sending  her home like that, halfnaked?  Do  you realize she'll probably end up  with pneumonia on account of you?
(shocked) George!

She puts a restraining hand on his arm. He shakes it off. She cannot know that George's tirade against Mrs. Welch i really a tirade against the world, against life itself,  against God. Over the phone we hear Mrs. Welch's voice  sputtering with protest.

Is this the sort of thing we pay  taxes for  to have teachers like  you? Silly, stupid, careless people  who send our kids home without any  clothes on? You know, maybe my kids  aren't the best-dressed kids; maybe  they don't have any decent clothes...
Mary succeeds in wresting the phone from George's hand.
Aw, that stupid...
Mary speaks quickly in to the phone.
Hello, Mrs. Welch. I want to  apologize...  hello... hello... (to George) She's hung up.
(savagely) I'll hang her up!
But the telephone is suddenly alive with a powerful male  voice calling:
Now, who do you think you are?
George hears this and grabs the receiver from Mary.
(to Mary) Wait a minute. (on phone) Hello? Who is this? Oh, Mr. Welch?   Okay, that's fine, Mr. Welch. Gives  me a chance to tell you what I really  think of your wife.
Mary once more tries to take the phone from him.
George...
(raving at her) Will you get out and let me handle  this? (into phone  shouting) Hello? Hello? What? Oh, you will,  huh?  Okay, Mr. Welch, any time you  think you're man enough... Hello?  Any...
But before he can think of an insult to top Welch's, we h a click on the phone.
Oh...
He hangs up the receiver, and turns toward the living roo His face is flushed and wet.
Daddy, how do you spell "Hallelujah"?
(shouts) How should I know? What do you think  I am, a dictionary?
He yells at Tommy, noisily playing with his vacuum cleane
Tommy, stop that! Stop it!
Janie is still practicing at the piano, monotonously.
(savagely) Janie, haven't you learned that silly  tune yet? You've played it over and  over again.  Now stop it! Stop it!

The room has suddenly become ominously quiet, the only SO being George's labored breathing. George goes over to a c of the room where his workshop is set up  a drawing table several models of modern buildings, bridges, etc. Savagel he kicks over the models, picks up some books and hurls t into the corner.  Mary and the children watch, horrified. George looks around and sees them staring at him as if he were some unknown wild animal.  The three children are cr
(gasping for breath) I'm sorry, Mary, Janie. I'm sorry. I  didn't mean... you go on and practice.   Pete, I owe you an apology, too. I'm  sorry. What do you want to know?
(holding back his  tears) Nothing, Daddy.
Mary and the children stare at him, stunned by his furiou outburst. There is silence in the room.
What's the matter with everybody?  Janie, go on. I told you to practice. (shouts) Now, go on, play!
Janie breaks into sobs.
Oh, Daddy...
(in an outburst) George, why must you torture the  children?  Why don't you...
The sight of Mary and the children suffering is too much George.
Mary...
He looks around him, then quickly goes out the front door the house. Mary goes to the phone, picks it up.
Bedford, two-four-seven, please.
Is Daddy in trouble?
Shall I pray for him?
Yes, Janie, pray very hard.
Me, too?
You too, Tommy. (on phone) Hello, Uncle Billy?
Potter is seated at his desk, his goon beside him. He is  signing some papers. George is seated in a chair before t desk, without a hat or coat, covered lightly with snow.

I'm in trouble, Mr. Potter. I need  help.  Through some sort of an  accident my company's short in their  accounts. The bank examiner's up  there today. I've got to raise eight  thousand dollars immediately.
(casually) Oh, so that's what the reporters  wanted to talk to you about?
(incredulous) The reporters?
Yes. They called me up from your  Building and Loan. Oh, there's a man  over there from the D.A.'s office,  too. He's looking for you.

(desperate) Please help me, Mr. Potter. Help me,  won't you please? Can't you see what  it means to my family? I'll pay you  any sort of a bonus on the loan...  any interest. If you still want the  Building and Loan, why I...
(interrupting) George, could it possibly be there's  a slight discrepancy in the books?
No, sir. There's nothing wrong with  the books. I've just misplaced eight  thousand dollars. I can't find it  anywhere.
(looking up) You misplaced eight thousand dollars?
Yes, sir.
Have you notified the police?
No, sir. I didn't want the publicity.   Harry's homecoming tomorrow...
(snorts) They're going to believe that one.  What've you been doing, George?  Playing the market with the company's  money?
No, sir. No, sir. I haven't.
What is it  a woman, then? You know,  it's all over town that you've been  giving money to Violet Bick.
(incredulous) What?
Not that it makes any difference to  me, but why did you come to me? Why  don't you go to Sam Wainwright and  ask him for the money?
I can't get hold of him. He's in  Europe.
Well, what about all your other  friends?
They don't have that kind of money,  Mr. Potter. You know that. You're  the only one in town that can help  me.
I see. I've suddenly become quite  important. What kind of security  would I have, George? Have you got  any stocks?
(shaking his head) No, sir.
Bonds? Real estate? Collateral of  any kind?
(pulls out policy) I have some life insurance, a fifteen  thousand dollar policy.
Yes... how much is your equity in  it?
Five hundred dollars.

(sarcastically) Look at you. You used to be so cocky!  You were going to go out and conquer  the world! You once called me a  warped, frustrated old man. What are  you but a warped, frustrated young  man? A miserable little clerk crawling  in here on your hands and knees and  begging for help. No securities  no  stocks  no bonds  nothing but a  miserable little five hundred dollar  equity in a life insurance policy.  You're worth more dead than alive.   Why don't you go to the riff-raff  you love so much and ask them to let  you have eight thousand dollar? You  know why? Because they'd run you out  of town on a rail... But I'll tell  you what I'm going to do for you,  George. Since the state examiner is  still here, as a stockholder of the  Building and Loan, I'm going to swear  out a warrant for your arrest.   Misappropriation of funds   manipulation  malfeasance...
George turns and starts out of the office as Potter picks the phone and dials.
All right, George, go ahead. You  can't hide in a little town like  this.
George is out of the door by now.  CAMERA MOVES CLOSER to Potter.
(on phone) Bill? This is Potter.

head_text.subj: EXT. MAIN STREET BEDFORD FALLS NIGHT

text: George comes out of the bank into the falling snow. He cr the street, tugs at the door of his old car, finally step over the door, and drives off.
An attractive little roadside tavern, with the name  "Martini's" in neon lights on the front wall.

The place is an Italian restaurant with bar. The bottles  sparkle.  There are Christmas greens and holly decorating the place. It has a warm, welcoming spirit, like Martini  himself, who is welcoming new arrivals. The booths and th checkered-cloth-covered tables are full. There is an air festivity and friendliness, and more like a party than a  public drinking place. George is seated at the bar  he ha had a great deal to drink, far more than he's accustomed
(greeting new customers) Merry Christmas. Glad you came.
How about some of that good spaghetti?
We got everything.
During this, CAMERA MOVES CLOSER to George. Nick, the  bartender, is watching him solicitously. Seated on the ot side of George is a burly individual, drinking a glass of beer. George is mumbling:
God... God... Dear Father in Heaven,  I'm not a praying man, but if you're  up there and you can hear me, show  me the way. I'm at the end of my  rope. Show me the way, God.
(friendly) Are you all right, George? Want  someone to take you home?
George shakes his head. Martini comes over to his side.
(worried) Why you drink so much, my friend?  Please go home, Mr. Bailey. This is  Christmas Eve.
The ugly man next to George, who has been listening, reac sharply to the name "Bailey."
Bailey? Which Bailey?
This is Mr. George Bailey.
Without any warning, the burly man throws a vicious punch George, who goes down and out. Martini, Nick and several  others rush to pick him up.

(to George) And the next time you talk to my  wife like that you'll get worse. She  cried for an hour. It isn't enough  she slaves teaching your stupid kids  how to read and write, and you have  to bawl her out...
(furious) You get out of here, Mr. Welch!
Mr. Welch reaches in his pocket for money.
Now wait... I want to pay for my  drink.
Never mind the money. You get out of  here quick.
All right.
You hit my best friend. Get out!
Nick and Martini shove Welch out the door, then run back help George to his feet. George's mouth is cut and bleedi
You all right, George?
(stunned) Who was that?
He's gone. Don't worry. His name is  Welch.  He don't come in to my place  no more.
Oh  Welch. That's what I get for  praying.
The last time he come in here. You  hear that, Nick?
Yes, you bet.
Where's my insurance policy? (finds it in pocket) Oh, here...
He starts for the door.
Oh, no, Please, don't go out this  way, Mr. Bailey.
I'm all right.
Nick and Martini try to stop him, but he shrugs them off.
Oh, no  you don't feel so good.
I'm all right.
Please don't go away  please!
George opens the door and exits to the street.

George's car comes along the empty street, through the fa snow, suddenly swerves and crashes into a tree near the  sidewalk of a house.  George gets out to look at the dama and savagely kicks at the open door of the car, trying to shut it. The noise brings the owner of the house running  out.
What do you think you're doing?

George stands unsteadily near the car, shaken by the acci The front lights are broken and the fender is ripped. Geo stands dully looking at the damage. The owner comes up,  looking at his tree. He leans over to examine the damages
(with indignation) Now look what you did. My  greatgrandfather planted this tree.
George staggers off down the street, paying no attention the man.
Hey, you... Hey, you! Come back here,  you drunken fool! Get this car out  of here!
George is crossing the approach to the bridge when a truc swings around the corner and nearly hits him.
Hey, what's the matter with you?   Look where you're going!
The truck turns onto the bridge, and George takes a narro catwalk at the railing.
George has stopped by the railing at the center of the br The snow is now falling hard.
CAMERA SHOOTING DOWN from George's angle TO the water, do with floating ice, passing under the bridge.
He stares down at the water, desperate, trying to make up his mind to act. He leans over looking at the water,  fascinated, glances furtively around him, hunches himself though about to jump.
From above George a body hurtles past and lands in the wa with a loud splash. George looks down, horrified.
(from river) Help! Help!
George quickly takes off his coat and dives over the rail into the water.
George comes up, sees the man flailing about in the water and CAMERA PANS WITH him as he swims toward the man.
Help! Help! Help!

head_text.subj: EXT. TOLL HOUSE ON BRIDGE NIGHT

text: The toll house keeper, hearing the cries for help, comes  running out on the bridge with a flashlight, which he shi on the two figures struggling in the water below.
The man in the water is Clarence, the angel whose voice w have heard speaking from Heaven. George reaches him, grab hold of him, and starts swimming for shore.

head_text.subj: INT. TOLL HOUSE ON BRIDGE NIGHT

text: George is seated before a wood-burning stove before which his clothes are drying on a line. He is in his long winte underwear.  He is sipping a mug of hot coffee, staring at the stove, cold, gloomy and drunk, ignoring Clarence and tollkeeper, preoccupied by his near suicide and his unsol problems.  Clarence is standing on the other side of the  stove, putting on his undershirt. This is a ludicrous  seventeenth century garment which looks like a baby's nig shirt  with embroidered cuffs and collar, and gathered at the neck with a drawstring. It falls below his knees.  Th tollkeeper is seated against the wall eyeing them  suspiciously. Throughout the scene he attempts to spit, b each time is stopped by some amazing thing Clarence does says.  Clarence becomes aware that his garment is amazing the tollkeeper.
I didn't have time to get some stylish  underwear. My wife gave me this on  my last birthday. I passed away in  it.

The tollkeeper, about to spit, is stopped in the middle o it by this remark. Clarence, secretly trying to get Georg attention, now picks up a copy of "Tom Sawyer" which is  hanging on the line, drying. He shakes the book.
Oh, Tom Sawyer's drying out, too.  You should read the new book Mark  Twain's writing now.
The tollkeeper stares at him incredulously.
How'd you happen to fall in?
I didn't fall in. I jumped in to  save George.
George looks up, surprised.
You what? To save me?
Well, I did, didn't I? You didn't go  through with it, did you?
Go through with what?
Suicide.
George and the tollkeeper react to this.
It's against the law to commit suicide  around here.
Yeah, it's against the law where I  come from, too.
Where do you come from?
He leans forward to spit, but is stopped by Clarence's ne statement.
Heaven. (to George) I had to act quickly; that's why I  jumped in. I knew if I were drowning  you'd try to save me. And you see,  you did, and that's how I saved you.
The tollkeeper becomes increasingly nervous. George casua looks at the strange smiling little man a second time.
(offhand) Very funny.
Your lip's bleeding, George.
George's hand goes to his mouth.
Yeah, I got a bust in the jaw in  answer to a prayer a little bit ago.
(comes around to George) Oh, no  no  no. I'm the answer to  your prayer. That's why I was sent  down here.
(casually interested) How do you know my name?
Oh, I know all about you. I've watched  you grow up from a little boy.
What are you, a mind reader or  something?
Oh, no.
Well, who are you, then?
Clarence Odbody, A-S-2.
Odbody... A-S-2. What's that A-S-2?
Angel, Second Class.

The tollkeeper's chair slips out from under him with a cr He has been leaning against the wall on it, tipped back o two legs.  Tollkeeper rises and makes his way warily out door. From his expression he looks like he'll call the ne cop.
(to tollkeeper) Cheerio, my good man.
George rubs his head with his hand, to clear his mind.
Oh, brother. I wonder what Martini  put in those drinks?
He looks up at Clarence standing beside him.
Hey, what's with you? What did you  say just a minute ago? Why'd you  want to save me?
That's what I was sent down for. I'm  your guardian angel.
I wouldn't be a bit surprised.
Ridiculous of you to think of killing  yourself for money. Eight thousand  dollars.
(bewildered) Yeah... just things like that. Now  how'd you know that?
I told you  I'm your guardian angel.  I know everything about you.
Well, you look about like the kind  of an angel I'd get. Sort of a fallen  angel, aren't you? What happened to  your wings?
I haven't won my wings yet. That's  why I'm an angel Second Class.
I don't know whether I like it very  much being seen around with an angel  without any wings.
Oh, I've got to earn them, and you'll  help me, won't you?
(humoring him) Sure, sure. How?
By letting me help you.
Only one way you can help me. You  don't happen to have eight thousand  bucks on you?
Oh, no, no. We don't use money in  Heaven.
Oh, that's right, I keep forgetting.  Comes in pretty handy down here,  bub.
Oh, tut, tut, tut.
I found it out a little late. I'm  worth more dead than alive.
Now look, you mustn't talk like that.  I won't get my wings with that  attitude. You just don't know all  that you've done. If it hadn't been  for you...

(interrupts) Yeah, if it hadn't been for me,  everybody'd be a lot better off. My  wife, and my kids and my friends. (annoyed with Clarence) Look, little fellow, go off and haunt  somebody else, will you?
No, you don't understand. I've got  my job...
(savagely) Aw, shut up, will you.
Clarence is not getting far with George. He glances up, p across the room, thoughtfully.
(to himself) Hmmm, this isn't going to be so easy. (to George) So you still think killing yourself  would make everyone feel happier,  eh?
(dejectedly) Oh, I don't know. I guess you're  right. I suppose it would have been  better if I'd never been born at  all.
What'd you say?
I said I wish I'd never been born.

Oh, you mustn't say things like that.   You... (gets an idea) ...wait a minute. Wait a minute.  That's an idea. (glances up toward  Heaven) What do you think? Yeah, that'll do  it.  All right. (to George) You've got your wish. You've never  been born.
As Clarence speaks this line, the snow stops falling outs the building, a strong wind springs up which blows open t door to the shack. Clarence runs to close the door.
(looking upward) You don't have to make all that fuss  about it.
As Clarence speaks, George cocks his head curiously, favo his deaf ear, more interested in his hearing than in what Clarence has said.
What did you say?
You've never been born. You don't  exist.  You haven't a care in the  world.
George feels his ear as Clarence talks.
No worries  no obligations  no  eight thousand dollars to get  no  Potter looking for you with the  Sheriff.
George indicates his bad ear.
Say something else in that ear.
(bending down) Sure. You can hear out of it.
Well, that's the doggonedest thing...  I haven't heard anything out of that  ear since I was a kid. Must have  been that jump in the cold water.
Your lip's stopped bleeding, too,  George.
George feels his lip, which shows no sign of the recent c he received from Welch. He is now thoroughly confused.
What do you know about that... What's  happened?
George looks around, as though to  get his bearings.
It's stopped snowing out, hasn't it?   What's happened here? (standing up) Come on, soon as these clothes of  ours are dry...
Our clothes are dry.
George feels the clothes on the line.
What do you know about that? Stove's  hotter than I thought. Now, come on,  get your clothes on, and we'll stroll  up to my car and get...
They start dressing. George interrupts himself.
Oh, I'm sorry. I'll stroll. You fly.
I can't fly. I haven't got any wings.
You haven't got your wings. Yeah,  that's right.

This is the same empty street where George's car swerved  into the tree near the sidewalk. George and Clarence come into shot and up to the spot where George had left his ca smashed against the tree. George looks around, but his ca is nowhere to be seen, and the tree is undamaged.
What's the matter?
(puzzled) Well, this is where I left my car  and it isn't here.
You have no car.
Well, I had a car, and it was right  here.  I guess somebody moved it.
The owner of the house passes with some Christmas package under his arm.
(politely) Good evening.
Oh, say... Hey... where's my car?
I beg your pardon?
My car, my car. I'm the fellow that  owns the car that ran into your tree.
What tree?
What do you mean, what tree? This  tree.  Here, I ran into it. Cut a  big gash in the side of it here.
The owner bends down to examine the trunk of the tree, th straightens up and smells George's breath. He backs away.
You must mean two other trees. You  had me worried. One of the oldest  trees in Pottersville.
(blankly) Pottersville? Why, you mean Bedford  Falls.
I mean Pottersville. (sharply) Don't you think I know where I live?   What's the matter with you?
The owner proceeds toward his house. George is completely bewildered.
Oh, I don't know. Either I'm off my  nut, or he is... (to Clarence) ...or you are!
It isn't me!
Well, maybe I left the car up at  Martini's. Well, come on, Gabriel.
He puts his arm around Clarence, and they start off up th road.
(as they go) Clarence!
Clarence! Clarence!

It is Martini's place, but almost unrecognizable. The che Italian feeling is gone. It is now more of a hard-drinkin joint, a honky-tonk. Same bar, tables have no covers. Peo are lower down and tougher. Nick the bartender is behind bar. George and Clarence come in. George does not notice difference, but Clarence is all eyes and beaming. They go to the bar.
(as they come in) That's all right. Go on in. Martini's  a good friend of mine.
Two people leave the bar as they approach.
There's a place to sit down. Sit  down.
Nick is wiping off the bar as they  sit down.
Oh, hello, Nick. Hey, where's Martini?
You want a martini?
No, no, Martini. Your boss. Where is  he?
(impatient) Look, I'm the boss. You want a drink  or don't you?
Okay  all right. Double bourbon,  quick, huh?
Okay. (to Clarence) What's yours?
I was just thinking... (face puckers up with  delicious anticipation) It's been so long since I...
(impatient) Look, mister, I'm standing here  waiting for you to make up your mind.

(appreciatively) That's a good man. I was just thinking  of a flaming rum punch. No, it's not  cold enough for that. Not nearly  cold enough...  Wait a minute...  wait a minute... I got it. Mulled  wine, heavy on the cinnamon and light  on the cloves. Off with you, me lad,  and be lively!

Hey, look mister, we serve hard drinks  in here for men who want to get drunk  fast.  And we don't need any  characters around to give the joint  atmosphere. Is that clear?  Or do I  have to slip you my left for a  convincer?
As he says this, Nick leans over the counter and puts his left fist nearly in Clarence's eye. Clarence is puzzled b this conduct.
(to George) What's he talking about?
(soothingly) Nick  Nick, just give him the same  as mine. He's okay.
Okay.
Nick turns away to get the drinks.
What's the matter with him. I never  saw Nick act like that before.
You'll see a lot of strange things  from now on.
Oh, yeah. Hey, little fellow  you  worry me. You got someplace to sleep?
No.
You don't huh? Well, you got any  money?
Nick is listening suspiciously to this conversation.
No.
No wonder you jumped in the river.
I jumped in the river to save you so  I could get my wings.
Nick stops pouring the drinks, bottle poised in his hand.
Oh, that's right.
A cash register bell rings off stage. Clarence reacts to SOUND of the bell.
Oh-oh. Somebody's just made it.
Made what?
Every time you hear a bell ring, it  means that some angel's just got his  wings.
George glances up at Nick.
Look, I think maybe you better not  mention getting your wings around  here.
Why? Don't they believe in angels?
(looking at Nick) A... Yeah, but... you know...
Then why should they be surprised  when they see one?
(to Nick) He never grew up. He's... (to Clarence) How old are you, anyway, Clarence?
Two hundred and ninety-three... (thinks) ...next May.
Nick slams the bottle down on the counter.
That does it! Out you two pixies go,  through the door or out the window!
Look, Nick. What's wrong?
(angrily) And that's another thing. Where do  you come off calling me Nick?
Well, Nick, that's your name, isn't  it?
What's that got to do with it? I  don't know you from Adam's off ox. (sees someone come in) Hey, you! Rummy! Come here! Come  here!
A small wreck of a man, with weak, watery eyes. Obviously broken-down panhandler, his hat in his hand.
He can hardly believe his eyes. It is Gower the druggist.

head_text.subj: BACK TO SHOT NICK AT THE BAR

text: (to Gower) Didn't I tell you never to come  panhandling around here?
Nick picks up a seltzer bottle, and squirts Gower in the  face with it. The crowd laugh brutally. Gower smiles weak as the soda runs off his face.
George, horrified, leaps up and goes over to Gower.
Mr. Gower! Mr. Gower! This is George  Bailey! Don't you know me?
No. No.
(to his bouncers) Throw him out. Throw him out.
The bouncers throw Gower out the front door. George rushe back to the bar.
(bewildered) Hey, what is... Hey, Nick, Nick...  Isn't that Mr. Gower, the druggist?

You know, that's another reason for  me not to like you. That rumhead  spent twenty years in jail for  poisoning a kid. If you know him,  you must be a jailbird yourself. (to his bouncers) Would you show these gentlemen to  the door.
Sure. This way, gentlemen.
George and Clarence come flying through the door and land the snow.
Nick at the cash register, busily ringing the bell.
Hey! Get me! I'm giving out wings!
George and Clarence lying in the snow. George has a stran puzzled look on his face. They remain for a moment as the landed, looking at each other.
You see, George, you were not there  to stop Gower from putting that poison  into the...
What do you mean, I wasn't there? I  remember distinctly...
George catches a glimpse of the front of the building wit the neon sign over the door. It now reads "NICK'S PLACE"  instead of "MARTINI'S." George and Clarence get to their feet.
(exasperated) What the... hey, what's going on  around here?  Why, this ought to be  Martini's place.
He points to the sign, and looks at Clarence. Clarence so of hangs his head. George fixes him with a very intereste look.
Look, who are you?
(patiently) I told you, George. I'm your guardian  angel.
George, still looking at him, goes up to him and pokes hi arm.  It's flesh.
Yeah, yeah, I know. You told me that.  What else are you? What... are you a  hypnotist?
No, of course not.
Well then, why am I seeing all these  strange things?
Don't you understand, George? It's  because you were not born.
Then if I wasn't born, who am I?
You're nobody. You have no identity.
George rapidly searches his pockets for identification, b without success.
What do you mean, no identity? My  name's George Bailey.

There is no George Bailey. You have  no papers, no cards, no driver's  license, no 4-F card, no insurance  policy... (he says these things  as George searches  for them) George looks in his watch pocket.
They're not there, either.
What?
Zuzu's petals.
George feverishly continues to turn his pockets inside ou
You've been given a great gift,  George. A chance to see what the  world would be like without you.
George is completely befuddled.
(shaking his head) Now wait a minute, here. Wait a minute  here. As, this is some sort of a  funny dream I'm having here. So long,  mister, I'm going home.
He starts off. Clarence rises.
Home? What home?

(furious) Now shut up! Cut it out! You're...   you're... you're crazy! That's what  I think... you're screwy, and you're  driving me crazy, too! I'm seeing  things. I'm going home and see my  wife and family. Do you understand  that? And I'm going home alone!
George strides off hurriedly. Clarence slowly follows him glancing up toward Heaven as he goes.
How'm I doing, Joseph. Thanks. (pause) No, I didn't have a drink!

The sign bearing the name of the town reads: "Pottersvill George looks at it in surprise, then starts up the street toward the main part of town. As he goes, CAMERA MOVES WI him. The character of the place has completely changed. W before it was a quiet, orderly small town, it has now bec in nature like a frontier village. We see a SERIES OF SHO of night clubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, pool halls an the like, with blaring jazz MUSIC issuing from the majori of them. The motion picture theatre has become a burlesqu house. Gower's drugstore is now a pawnbroker's establishm and so on.

George stops before what used to be the offices of the  Building and Loan.  There is a garish electric sign over entrance reading: "Welcome Jitterbugs." A crowd of people are watching the police, who are raiding the place, and  dragging out a number of screaming women, whom they throw into a patrol wagon. George talks to one of the cops:
Hey... hey. Where did the Building  and Loan move to?
The Building and what?
The Bailey Building and Loan. It was  up there.
They went out of business years ago.
George sees the struggling figure of Violet Bick, arrayed a tart, being dragged into the patrol wagon.
Hey, Violet! (to the cop) Hey, listen  that's Violet Bick!
I know. I know.
I know that girl!
The cop shoves George to one side. He looks around and se Ernie's taxi cruising slowly by.
Hey, Ernie  Ernie!
Ernie stops the cab, and George enters it.
Ernie, take me home. I'm off my nut!
(a much harder Ernie) Where do you live?
Aw, now, doggone it, Ernie, don't  you start pulling that stuff. You  know where I live. Three-twenty  Sycamore. Now hurry up.
Okay. Three-twenty Sycamore?...
Yeah  yeah  hurry up. Zuzu's sick.
All right.  He pulls down the flag  on the meter and starts the cab.
Ernie is puzzled by the stranger.

Look here, Ernie, straighten me out  here.  I've got some bad liquor or  something.  Listen to me now. Now,  you are Ernie Bishop, and you live  in Bailey Park with your wife and  kid? That's right, isn't it?
(suspiciously) You seen my wife?
(exasperated) Seen your wife? I've been to your  house a hundred times.
Look, bud, what's the idea?  I live  in a shack in Potter's Field and my  wife ran away three years ago and  took the kid...  And I ain't never  seen you before in my life.
Okay. Just step on it. Just get me  home.

Ernie turns to driving, but he's worried about his passen As he passes the burlesque house he sees Bert the cop sta beside his police car. Attracting his attention, he motio to Bert to follow him, indicating he has a nut in the bac Bert gets into his car and follows.
The taxi pulls up to the curb and stops.
The cab is parked. George gets out and looks at the house
Is this the place?
Of course it's the place.
Well, this house ain't been lived in  for twenty years.

George is stopped momentarily by the appearance of the ho Windows are broken, the porch sags, one section of the ro has fallen, doors and shutters hang askew on their hinges Like a doomed man, George approaches the house.
The police car has pulled up beside the cab, and Bert and Ernie stand watching George's actions.
What's up, Ernie?
I don't know, but we better keep an  eye on this guy. He's bats.
Ernie switches on the spotlight on his cab, and turns the beam toward the old house.

The interior of the house is lit up here and there, ghost by Ernie's spotlight. No furniture, cobwebs, wallpaper ha and swinging  stairs are broken and collapsed. In a voice that sounds like a cry for help, George yells out:
Mary! Mary! Tommy! Pete! Janie! Zuzu!   Where are you?
Clarence suddenly appears leaning against a wall.
They're not here, George. You have  no children.
(ignoring him) Where are you? (then, to Clarence) What have you done with them?
Bert is standing in the entrance, with his gun in his han Ernie is a few feet behind him, ready to run.
All right, put up your hands. No  fast moves. Come on out here, both  of you.
Bert! Thank heaven you're here!
He rushes toward Bert.
Stand back.
Bert, what's happened to this house?   Where's Mary? Where's my kids?
(warningly) Watch him, Bert.
Come on, come on.
(bewildered) Bert  Ernie! What's the matter with  you two guys? You were here on my  wedding night. You, both of you,  stood out here on the porch and sung  to us, don't you remember?
(nervously) Think I'd better be going.
Look, now why don't you be a good  kid and we'll take you in to a doctor.   Everything's going to be all right.
Bert tries to lead George away by the arm, but George  struggles with him, trying to explain.
Bert, now listen to me. Ernie, will  you take me over to my mother's house?  Bert, listen! (gesturing to Clarence) It's that fellow there  he says  he's an angel  he's tried to  hypnotize me.
I hate to do this, fella.
Bert raises his gun to hit George on the head. As he does so, Clarence darts in and fixes his teeth in Bert's wrist forcing him to let George go.
Run... George! Run, George!
George dashes out of the house and down the street, as Be grapples with Clarence, and they fall to the ground,  wrestling. We see Bert kneeling, trying to put handcuffs Clarence.
Help! Joseph, help!
Oh, shut up!
Help, oh Joseph, help! Joseph!
Suddenly Clarence disappears from under Bert's hands. Ber gets up, amazed by his vanishing.
Where'd he go? Where'd he go? I had  him right here.
Ernie's hair is now standing on end with fright.
(stammering) I need a drink.
He runs out of the scene.
Well, which way'd they go? Help me  find 'em.

George runs up the path to the front door of the house an raps on the door. He rings the bell and taps on the glass when his attention is caught by a sign on the wall readin "Ma Bailey's Boarding House."

The door opens and a woman appears. It is Mrs. Bailey, bu she has changed amazingly. Her face is harsh and tired. I her eyes, once kindly and understanding, there is now col suspicion. She gives no sign that she knows him.
Well?
Mother...
Mother? What do you want?
It is a cruel blow to George.
Mother, this is George. I thought  sure you'd remember me.
(coldly) George who? If you're looking for a  room there's no vacancy.
She starts to close the door, but George stops her.
Oh, Mother, Mother, please help me.   Something terrible's happened to me.  I don't know what it is. Something's  happened to everybody. Please let me  come in. Keep me here until I get  over it.
Get over what? I don't take in  strangers unless they're sent here  by somebody I know.
(desperate) Well, I know everybody you know.  Your brother-in-law, Uncle Billy.
(suspiciously) You know him?
Well, sure I do.
When'd you see him last?
Today, over at the house.
That's a lie. He's been in the insane  asylum ever since he lost his  business.  And if you ask me, that's  where you belong.
She slams the door shut in George's face.

George stands a moment, stunned. Then he turns and runs o to the sidewalk, until his face fills the screen. His fea are distorted by the emotional chaos within him. We see  Clarence leaning on the mail box at the curb, holding his volume of "Tom Sawyer" in his hand.
Strange, isn't it?  Each man's life  touches so many other lives, and  when he isn't around he leaves an  awful hole, doesn't he?

(quietly, trying to  use logic) I've heard of things like this. You've  got me in some kind of a spell, or  something.  Well, I'm going to get  out of it. I'll get out of it. I  know how, too. I... the last man I  talked to before all this stuff  started happening to me was Martini.
You know where he lives?
Sure I know where he lives. He lives  in Bailey Park.
They walk out of scene.
George and Clarence approach the tree from which the "Bai Park" sign once hung. Now it is just outside a cemetery,  with graves where the houses used to be.
Are you sure this is Bailey Park?
Oh, I'm not sure of anything anymore.  All I know is this should be Bailey  Park. But where are the houses?
The two walk into the cemetery.
(as they go) You weren't here to build them.
George wandering like a lost soul among the tombstones,  Clarence trotting at his heels. Again George stops to sta with frightened eyes at:
Upon it is engraved a name, Harry Bailey. Feverishly Geor scrapes away the snow covering the rest of the inscriptio and we read: "IN MEMORY OF OUR BELOVED SON  HARRY BAILEY
Your brother, Harry Bailey, broke  through the ice and was drowned at  the age of nine.
George jumps up.
That's a lie! Harry Bailey went to  war! He got the Congressional Medal  of Honor! He saved the lives of every  man on that transport.

(sadly) Every man on that transport died.  Harry wasn't there to save them  because you weren't there to save  Harry. You see, George, you really  had a wonderful life.  Don't you see  what a mistake it would be to throw  it away?
Clarence...
Yes, George?
Where's Mary?
Oh, well, I can't...
I don't know how you know these  things, but tell me  where is she?
George grabs Clarence by the coat collar and shakes him.
If you know where she is, tell me  where my wife is.
I'm not supposed to tell.
(becoming violent) Please, Clarence, tell me where she  is.
You're not going to like it, George.
(shouting) Where is she?
She's an old maid. She never married.
(choking him) Where's Mary? Where is she?
She's...
Where is she?
(in self-defense) She's just about to close up the  library!
George lets Clarence go, and runs off. Clarence falls to ground, where he rubs his neck.
(to himself) There must be some easier way for me  to get my wings.

Mary comes out the door, then turns and locks it. We see  George watching her from the sidewalk. Mary is very diffe no buoyancy in her walk, none of Mary's abandon and love  of life.  Glasses, no make-up, lips compressed, elbows cl to body. She looks flat and dried up, and extremely self- satisfied and efficient.
George, as he watches her.
George and Mary, on the sidewalk.
Mary!
She looks up, surprised, but, not recognizing him, contin on.
Mary!
Mary starts to run away from him, and he follows, despera
Mary! Mary!
He catches up to her, grabs her by the arms, and keeps a  tight grip on her. She struggles to free herself.
Mary, it's George! Don't you know  me?  What's happened to us?
(struggling) I don't know you! Let me go!
Mary, please! Oh, don't do this to  me.  Please, Mary, help me. Where's  our kids? I need you, Mary! Help me,  Mary!
Mary breaks away from him, and dashes into the first door she comes to, the Blue Moon Bar.

Small tables, booths, perhaps a counter. It is crowded. M of the people are the same who were present during the ru on the Building and Loan. Mary comes running in, screamin The place goes into an uproar. George comes in, practical insane. Some of the men grab and hold on to him.
(shouting) Mary... (to men holding him) Let me go! Mary, don't run away!
Somebody call the police!
Hit him with a bottle!
He needs a strait jacket!
(from back of room) That man  stop him!
(recognizing some of  them) Tom! Ed! Charlie! That's my wife!
Mary lets out a final scream, then faints into the arms o couple of women at the bar.
Mary!
Oh, no you don't!
(screaming) Mary!
George can't fight through the men holding him. Desperate he thinks of Clarence, and heads for the door.
Clarence! Clarence! Where are you?
Just as George breaks through the door, Bert arrives in h police car. He gets out and heads for the door, to run in George as he comes out.
Oh, it's you!

He grabs for George, who lets him have one square on the  button, knocking him down, then continues running down th street yelling for Clarence. Bert gets up, takes out his and fires several shots after the fleeing figure.
(to crowd) Stand back!
Bert gets into the police car, and, siren screaming, sets off in pursuit of George.

The same part of the bridge where George was standing bef Clarence jumped in. The wind is blowing as it has all thr this sequence. George comes running into shot. He is  frantically looking for Clarence.
Clarence! Clarence! Help me, Clarence.  Get me back. Get me back. I don't  care what happens to me. Only get me  back to my wife and kids. Help me,  Clarence, please!  Please! I want to  live again!
George leaning on the bridge railing, praying.
I want to live again. I want to live  again. Please, God, let me live again.
George sobs. Suddenly, toward the end of the above, the w dies down. A soft, gentle snow begins to fall.
The police car pulls up on the roadway behind him, and Be comes into scene.
Hey, George! George! You all right?
George backs away and gets set to hit Bert again.
Hey, what's the matter?
(warningly) Now get out of here, Bert, or I'll  hit you again! Get out!
What the Sam Hill you yelling for,  George?
Don't... George?
George talks hopefully  George touches Bert unbelievingly George's mouth is bleeding again.
Bert, do you know me?

Know you? Are you kiddin'? I've been  looking all over town trying to find  you.  I saw your car piled into that  tree down there, and I thought  maybe... Hey, your mouth's bleeding;  are you sure you're all right?
What did...
George touches his lips with his tongue, wipes his mouth  with his hand, laughs happily. His rapture knows no bound
(joyously) My mouth's bleeding, Bert! My mouth's  bleed... (feeling in watch  pocket) Zuzu's petals! Zuzu's... they're...   they're here, Bert! What do you know  about that? Merry Christmas!
He practically embraces the astonished Bert, then runs at top speed toward town.
George runs away from camera yelling
Mary! Mary!
George's wrecked car is smashed against the tree. He come running into shot, sees the car, lets out a triumphant ye pats the car, and dashes on.

head_text.subj: EXT. MAIN STREET BEDFORD FALLS NIGHT

text: George sees that the "POTTERSVILLE" sign is now replaced the original "YOU ARE NOW IN BEDFORD FALLS" sign.
Hello, Bedford Falls!
He turns and runs through the falling snow up the main st of the town. As he runs, he notices that the town is back its original appearance. He passes some late shoppers on street
Merry Christmas!
(ad lib) Merry Christmas! Merry Christmas,  George!
Merry Christmas, movie house!
Merry Christmas, emporium!

head_text.subj: EXT. BUILDING AND LOAN OFICES NIGHT

text: Merry Christmas, you wonderful old  Building and Loan!
George notices a light in Potter's office window, and rac across the street.
Potter is seated working at his desk, his goon by his sid George pounds on the window.
(from outside) Merry Christmas, Mr. Potter!
George runs off as Potter looks up from his work.
Happy New Year to you  in jail! Go  on home  they're waiting for you!
The lights are on. There is a fire in the fireplace. The  Christmas tree is fully decorated with presents stacked  around.
Carter, the bank examiner, a newspaper reporter and  photographer, and a sheriff, are waiting in the hall for  George. George comes dashing in the front door.
(excitedly) Mary... (sees the men) Well, hello, Mr. Bank Examiner!
He grabs his hand and shakes it.
(surprised) Mr. Bailey, there's a deficit!
I know. Eight thousand dollars.
(reaching into pocket) George, I've got a little paper here.
(happily) I'll bet it's a warrant for my arrest.   Isn't it wonderful? Merry Christmas!
The photographer sets off a flash bulb.
Reporters? Where's Mary? (calling) Mary!
George runs to the kitchen. He gets no answer. As he goes
Oh, look at this wonderful old drafty  house! Mary! Mary!
He comes running back to the hall.
Have you seen my wife?
Merry Christmas, Daddy! Merry  Christmas, Daddy!
The three children are at the top of the stairs. They are their pajamas.
Kids!
George starts to run up the stairs, and the old familiar  knob on the banister comes off in his hand. He kisses it  lovingly and puts it back, then continues up the stairs.
Pete  kids  Janie  Tommy. (takes them in his  arms) I could eat you up!
George and the kids. He is hugging them.
Where's your mother?
She went looking for you with Uncle  Billy.
Zuzu comes running out of her bedroom. George crushes her him.
Daddy!
Zuzu  Zuzu. My little gingersnap!  How do you feel?
Fine.
And not a smitch of temperature.
(laughing) Not a smitch of temp...
As Mary comes through the door, breathless and excited. T four men are watching with open mouths.
Hallelujah!
(to the men) Hello. (sees George) George! Darling!
Mary races up the stairs, where George meets her in a fie embrace.
Mary! Mary!
George, darling! Where have you been?
George and Mary embrace tearfully.
Oh, George, George, George.
Mary! Let me touch you! Oh, you're  real!
Oh, George, George!
You have no idea what's happened to  me.
You have no idea what happened...
He stops her with a kiss. She leads him excitedly down th stairs.
Well, come on, George, come on  downstairs quick. They're on their  way.
All right.
Mary leads George, who is carrying a couple of the kids o his back, to a position in front of the Christmas tree.
Come on in here now. Now, you stand  right over here, by the tree. Right  there, and don't move, don't move. I  hear 'em now, George, it's a miracle!  It's a miracle!

She runs toward front door and flings it open. Ad lib SOU of an excited crowd can be heard. Uncle Billy, face flush covered with snow, and carrying a clothes basket filled w money, bursts in. He is followed by Ernie, and about twen more townspeople.
Come in, Uncle Billy! Everybody! In  here!

Uncle Billy Mary and the crowd come into the living room. table stands in front of George. George picks up Zuzu to  protect her from the mob. Uncle Billy dumps the basketful money out onto the table  the money overflows and falls a over.
Isn't it wonderful?

The rest of the crowd all greet George with greetings and smiles.  Each one comes forward with money. In their pock in shoe boxes, in coffee pots. Money pours onto the table pennies, dimes, quarters, dollar bills  small money, but  lots of it. Mrs. Bailey and Mrs. Hatch push toward George More people come in. The place becomes a bedlam.
