Shouts o "Gangway  gangway" as a new bunch comes in and pours out  its money. Mary stands next to George, watching him. Geor stands there overcome and speechless as he holds Zuzu. As sees the familiar faces, he gives them sick grins.  Tears course down his face. His lips frame their names as he gr them.

(emotionally at the  breaking point) Mary did it, George! Mary did it!  She told a few people you were in  trouble and they scattered all over  town collecting money.  They didn't  ask any questions  just said: "If  George is in trouble  count on me."  You never saw anything like it.
Tom comes in, digging in his purse as he comes.
What is this, George? Another run on  the bank?
Charlie adds his money to the pile.
Here you are, George. Merry Christmas.
Ernie is trying to get some system into the chaos.
The line forms on the right.
Mr. Martini comes in bearing a mixing bowl overflowing wi cash.
Mr. Martini! Merry Christmas! Step  right up here.
Martini dumps his money on the table.
I busted the juke-box, too!
Mr. Gower enters with a large glass jar jammed full of no
Mr. Gower!
(to George) I made the rounds of my charge  accounts.
Violet Bick arrives, and takes out the money George had g her for her trip to New York.
Violet Bick!
I'm not going to go, George. I changed  my mind.
Annie, the colored maid, enters, digging money out of a l black stocking.
I've been saving this money for a  divorce, if ever I get a husband.
Mr. Partridge, the high school principal, is the next don
There you are, George. I got the  faculty all up out of bed. (hands his watch to  Zuzu) And here's something for you to play  with.
(giving money) I wouldn't have a roof over my head  if it wasn't for you, George.
Ernie is reading a telegram he has just received.

Just a minute. Quiet, everybody.  Quiet  quiet. Now, this is from  London. (reading) Mr. Gower cables you need cash. Stop.  My office instructed to advance you  up to twenty-five thousand dollars.  Stop. Heehaw and Merry Christmas.  Sam Wainwright.
The crowd breaks into a cheer as Ernie drops the telegram top of the pile of money on the table.
(calling out) Mr. Martini. How about some wine?

As various members of the family bring out a punch bowl a glasses, Janie sits down at the piano and strikes a chord She starts playing "Hark! The Herald Angels Sing," and th entire crowd joins in the singing. We see a SERIES OF SHO of the various groups singing the hymn, and some people a still coming in and dropping their money on the table. Ca the bank examiner, makes a donation; the sheriff sheepish looks at George and tears his warrant in small pieces. In the midst of this scene, Harry, in Naval uniform, enters, accompanied by Bert, the cop.
Hello, George, how are you?
Harry... Harry...
(as he sees the money) Mary  looks like I got here too  late.
Mary, I got him here from the airport  as quickly as I could. The fool flew  all the way up here in a blizzard.
Mrs. Bailey enters scene.
Harry, how about your banquet in New  York?
Oh, I left right in the middle of it  as soon as I got Mary's telegram.
Ernie hands Harry a glass of wine.
Good idea, Ernie. A toast... to my  big brother, George. The richest man  in town!
Once more the crowd breaks into cheering and applause. Ja at the piano and Bert on his accordion start playing "Aul Lang syne," and everyone joins in.

George, still holding Zuzu in his arms, glances down at t pile of money on the table. His eye catches something on of the pile, and he reaches down for it. It is Clarence's copy of "Tom Sawyer." George opens it and finds an inscri written in it: "Dear George, remember no man is a failure who has friends. Thanks for the wings, Love Clarence."
(looking at book) What's that?
That's a Christmas present from a  very dear friend of mine.

At this moment, perhaps because of the jostling of some o the people on the other side of the tree, a little silver bell on the Christmas tree swings to and fro with a silve tinkle. Zuzu closes the cover of the book, and points to bell.
Look, Daddy. Teacher says, every  time a bell rings an angel gets his  wings.
(smiling) That's right, that's right.
He looks up toward the ceiling and winks.
Attaboy, Clarence.
The voices of the people singing swell into a final cresc for the
